rows.title: Meditation

transcript.eng:
Today's pause is called loving kindness meditation.
Find a comfortable sitting position, your feet flat on the floor, your hands resting in your lap.
Close your eyes if you are comfortable, or maintain a soft gaze. 
Ask yourself, “What is my experience in this moment?” 
Notice what thoughts you are experiencing. 
Notice how you feel emotionally. 
Notice how your body feels. Notice any discomfort or tension.
Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. 
You can then say the following words silently to yourself: 
May I be peaceful. 
May I be safe. 
May I be healthy. 
May I be happy. 
May I feel loved. 
Repeat slowly once or twice, taking your time between each phrase.
If you feel comfortable, you can also send thoughts of loving-kindness to your child, your partner, your family, and anyone else who is close to you in your life.
Now, allow your focus to expand to the whole body. 
Allow your focus to expand to the sounds in the room. 
Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. 
Open your eyes, and when you are ready, continue to your lesson with a sense of calm. 
Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us.

rows.text_1:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 
Noticing  emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 
Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions – even the difficult ones.
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don’t know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

rows.text_1: Let’s check in on another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f1_father.name: “@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?”
 @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Let’s play with the ball outside!”

@data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “I can’t do it!”
 @data.characters.f1_father.name: “I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name. It’s not easy, let’s practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.”

@data.characters.f1_father.name: “Five catches in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name!”
 @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name: “Let’s do 10!”
@data.characters.f1_father.name: “Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name.”

rows.text_1: Let’s talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f1_father.name and @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name decided to play catch?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help her recognize her feelings so she can handle them better next time.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That’s right. By naming @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s emotions, @data.characters.f1_father.name models an important skill.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name recognize her emotions. Once she knows what she’s feeling, she’ll be better at solving problems next time.
rows.quiz_1_question: Why does @data.characters.f1_father.name name @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s feelings when she’s feeling angry and proud?
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: To help @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name learn to recognise her own emotions
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: To teach @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name how to solve problems on her own.
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: To distract @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name from what’s bothering her.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Not quite. The goal isn’t to take her mind off her feelings. By naming her emotions, @data.characters.f1_father.name is helping @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name understand what she’s feeling, so she can deal with it better next time.
rows.quiz_2_question: What can we learn from how @data.characters.f1_father.name talks about @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s emotions?
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Yes, @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us that it is important to identify  both positive *and* difficult emotions for our children.
rows.quiz_2_option_2_text: He accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s is feeling
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Yes, @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.
rows.quiz_2_option_3_text: He uses words to describe @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s emotions
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Yes, @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.
rows.quiz_2_option_4_text: He shares his own feelings with @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4: Yes, by talking about his own feeling of happiness,  @data.characters.f1_father.name models how his daughter can do the same.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_5: Yes, @data.characters.f1_father.name shows us that his daughter’s difficult emotions are not something she needs to ignore or be scared of..
rows.quiz_3_question: What would have happened if @data.characters.f1_father.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name’s frustration?
rows.quiz_3_feedback_1: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to help our children learn how do deal with their feelings before they get too big.
rows.quiz_3_option_2_text: The same problem would happen again next time
rows.quiz_3_feedback_2: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.
rows.quiz_3_option_3_text: @data.characters.f1_daughter_6.name would not have learned how to catch a ball
rows.quiz_3_feedback_3: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.text_1: With these three tips, you can help your child learn to manage their emotions well.
rows.section_1_text: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.
rows.section_1_extra_text: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child’s words and actions.
rows.section_2_text: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:
 Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.  
 Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.
 Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.
 Disgusted: Move away from somethingt you don't like.
 Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
 Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
rows.section_3_text:
Use words to describe your and your child’s emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Describe how you see your child’s emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*“I notice you’re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry?”*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*“I know I feel the same way when I can’t go out when I want to.”*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.text_1:
Okay let’s put these tips to work: 
Try to notice your child’s feelings, and describe both your own feelings and the feelings of your child at least once a day.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he’s feeling.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!
rows.quiz_1_question: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
My daughter used to get so frustrated and angry when she did not get her way. She would shout and scream, even when we went out, and I would also feel very angry and embarrassed. 

When I learned about emotions, I started to name and acknowledge her emotions. I helped her understand that it is okay to feel angry sometimes, but that she can show it in a different way. Now, she will tell me when she starts to feel angry, and we can find a solution together that works for everyone.

rows.text_1: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!
rows.quiz_1_question: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?
